metadata.case_name: Central Inland Water Transport Corporation Limited v. Inland Steam Navigation Workers Union & Anr.

facts.text: River Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. (Company) operated river service from West Bengal to Assam through former East Pakistan, employing about 8,000 workmen including clerical staff.
Due to conflict with Pakistan in 1965, Company suspended major operations, undertook large-scale retrenchment, incurring heavy losses despite Government of India acquiring controlling interest.
Settlement dated August 25, 1965 between Company and respondent Union: valid for 5 years till end of 1969, retiring age 57 years, no retrenchment for 5 years.
In 1966, due to indebtedness to creditors including Union of India, State Bank of India, Chartered Bank (several crores of rupees), winding up petition filed in Calcutta High Court.
Company applied under Sections 391-394 Companies Act for scheme of arrangement and compromise with appellant Corporation (incorporated February 22, 1967 as wholly owned Central Government Company).
Scheme sanctioned by single Judge, Calcutta High Court on May 3, 1967. Union appeared to safeguard workers' interests.
Division Bench upheld scheme on July 14, 1967, leaving open questions on closure under Industrial Disputes Act, enforceability of 1965 settlement, workers' claims, for proper forum.

Scheme: All properties/assets (some liabilities) vest in Corporation; Corporation to take over as many staff/labour as possible (discretionary); non-taken employees paid compensation by Company from Government funds; Company closed and dissolved without winding up on payment of creditors.
Company issued notice of closure on May 3, 1967. Corporation issued fresh appointment letters, employed 5173 out of 8000 former employees.
Government of West Bengal made two references under s.33C(2) on September 12, 1968: compute benefits under 1965 settlement and retrenchment benefits under s.25FF.
Corporation's writ petition: references set aside by B.C. Mittra J. on July 15, 1969 as misconceived; liberty to make fresh references.

Consolidated reference by West Bengal Government on October 27, 1969 to Second Labour Court under s.33C(2) re: 420 employees (List I, bound by 1965 settlement) and 92 (List II) claiming benefits/ retrenchment compensation; issues on transfer, binding settlement, continuance in employment, recoverability, s.25FF, closure under s.25FFF.
Corporation's writ petition under Art.226: Ghose J. struck down issue 4 (closure s.25FFF), upheld jurisdiction on issues 1-3.
Division Bench dismissed Corporation's appeal on December 14, 1972 re: jurisdiction on issues 1-3. Certificate refused July 20, 1973; special leave granted by Supreme Court.
Out of 512 employees in reference, 24 re-employed later by Corporation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Labour Court has jurisdiction under section 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act to adjudicate the referred issues on transfer of undertaking, binding nature of 1965 settlement, entitlement to continuance in employment, recoverability from Corporation, retrenchment compensation under s.25FF.

petitioner_arguments.text: References under s.33C(2) make unjustified assumptions, non-justiciable; Labour Court lacks jurisdiction as issues involve determination of rights/liabilities, not mere computation of existing benefits.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 33C(2) Industrial Disputes Act; analogous to execution proceedings

petitioner_arguments.text: No existing right adjudicated; scheme did not compel employment or pass responsibilities; s.25FF liability on transferor, not transferee.

respondent_arguments.text: Workers in List I entitled under 1965 settlement (binding on successors under s.18(3)); Corporation as successor must continue employment till 1969; refusal wrongful, deem continuous service for computation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Settlement dated 25.08.1965; Section 18(3) Industrial Disputes Act

court_reasoning.text: Proceedings under s.33C(2) are execution-like, for computing existing adjudicated/provided benefits; cannot investigate rights/liabilities (determinations i & ii).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Labour Court limited to incidental identity issues, not principal adjudications like entitlement or liability.

court_reasoning.text: Referred issues require determining if undertaking transferred, settlement binding on Corporation, entitlement to employment/ compensation, recoverability - major industrial dispute outside s.33C(2) scope.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Such investigation for Industrial Tribunal under s.10, not Labour Court.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme left employment discretionary; s.25FF terminates employment on transfer, compensation against transferor; no liability on transferee for reemployment/compensation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if successor, s.25FF prevails over settlement prohibiting retrenchment.

holdings.text: Labour Court has no jurisdiction under s.33C(2) to adjudicate the referred issues.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chief Mining Engineer, East India Coal Co. Ltd. v. Rameshwar
precedents_cited.relevance: s.33C(2) proceedings analogous to execution; existing right required.

precedents_cited.case_name: State Bank of Bikaner and Jaipur v. R. Khandelwal
precedents_cited.relevance: Cannot claim under s.33C(2) matters needing s.10 reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagopalan
precedents_cited.relevance: Incidental enquiry on identity ok; not rights/liability; illustrations of non-jurisdiction like wrongful dismissal.

precedents_cited.case_name: South Arcot Electricity Company v. N. K. Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: s.25FF conditions for no compensation on transfer.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anakapalli Co-operative Agricultural Industrial Society Limited v. Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Effect of s.25FF: termination on transfer, compensation vs transferor; no claim vs transferee; successor factors.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction under 33C(2) limited to computation; 25FF on transfer compensation; settlement binding; closure.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Scheme of arrangement and compromise sanctioned.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; Labour Court held without jurisdiction under s.33C(2) on issues 1-3; no order as to costs. Civil Appeal No.1780 rendered infructuous.
outcome.relief_granted: Reference to Labour Court set aside insofar as issues 1-3.

key_quotes.text: Proceedings under section 33C(2) are analogous to execution proceedings and the Labour Court... is in the position of an executing court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of Labour Court's jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: The computation itself is consequential upon and subsidiary to determinations i and ii as the last stage in the process which commenced with a reference to the Industrial Tribunal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why rights/liability determination not incidental.

key_quotes.text: By merely making a claim in a loaded form the workmen cannot give the Labour Court jurisdiction under s.33C(2).
key_quotes.speaker: court
